item.title: Existence of a Solution in the Open Interval (0, 1) for a Cubic Equation with Real Coefficients
item.description:
Let $a,b,c\in \mathbb{R}$. Show that there exists $x\in (0,1)$ such that

$$4ax^3+3bx^2+2cx=a+b+c.$$

Show Hint:
Apply the Rolle's Theorem to the function $\varphi:[0,1]\to \mathbb{R}, t\mapsto at^4+bt^3+ct^2-(a+b+c)t$.

item.title: Lipschitz Continuity and Bounded Derivatives of Differentiable Functions
item.description:
Let $I$ be an interval of $\mathbb{R}$ and $f:I\to\mathbb{R}$ be differentiable.

Show that $f$ is a Lipshitz continuous function if, and only if, its derivative is bounded.

Show Answer:
$(\Leftarrow)$ In accordance with the mean value inequality.

$(\Rightarrow)$ If $f$ is $k$ Lipshitz continuous then for all $x,y\in I$ such that $x\ne y$ we have $$\left|\frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y}\right|\le k.$$ In the limit as $y\to x$, we obtain $∣f'(x)∣\le k$. Consequently, $f'$ is bounded.

item.title: Convergence of Sequences Given a Quadratic Sum Condition
item.description:
Let $(u_n)$ and $(v_n)$ be two real sequences such that

$$ u_n^2+ u_n v_n + v_n^2 \xrightarrow[n\to+\infty] {}0.$$

Prove that the sequences $(u_n)$ and $(v_n)$ converge to 0.

Show Answer:
We have $$0\le (u_n+v_n)^2= u_n^2+2u_n v_n+ v_n^2\le 2(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0.$$ Hence $u_n+v_n \xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$. Also $$u_n v_n= (u_n+v_n)^2 -(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$$ so $$u_n^2+v_n^2= 2(u_n^2+u_n v_n+ v_n^2)-(u_n+v_n)^2\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$$ which allows to conclude that $u_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$ and $v_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}0$.

item.title: Divergence of Harmonic Series and Sequence Behavior at Infinity
item.description:
Let $(H_n)$ the sequence defined for $n\in \mathbb{N}$ by $$H_n= \sum_{k=1}^n \frac 1k.$$

  1. Prove that $H_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.
  2. Let $(u_n)$ a sequence such that $n(u_{n+1}-u_n)\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}1$. Prove that $u_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.
Show Answer:
1. Knowing $\ln(1+x)\le x$, we have $$\frac1k\ge \ln\left(1+\frac1k\right)=\ln(k+1)-\ln k$$ so $$H_n\ge \sum_{k=1}^n \ln(k+1)-\ln k= \ln(n+1)$$ and then $H_n\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.

2. There exists $N\in \mathbb{N}$ such that for all $n\ge N$, $$n(u_{n+1}-u_{n})\ge 1/2.$$ Hence $$ u_{n+1}-u_{N}\ge \sum_{k=N}^n u_{k+1}-u_{k}\ge \frac12 \sum_{k=N}^n\frac1k= \frac12(H_{n}-H_{N-1})\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$$ and then $u_{n}\xrightarrow[n\to+\infty]{}+\infty$.

item.title: Boundedness of Continuous and Periodic Functions on $\mathbb{R}$
item.description:
Show that a continuous and periodic function defined on $\mathbb{R}$ is bounded.

Show Answer:
Let $T>0$ be a period of $f$. On $[0,T]$, $f$ is bounded by some $M$ because $f$ is continuous on a closed and bounded interval. For any $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x−nT\in[0,T]$ for $n=\lfloor x/T\rfloor$, so $∣f(x)∣=∣f(x−nT)∣≤M$. Thus, $f$ is bounded by $M$ on $\mathbb{R}$.

item.title: Fixed Point Theorem for Continuous Functions on a Closed Interval
item.description:
Let $f:[0,1]\to [0,1]$ be a continuous function. Show that $f$ has a fixed point.

Show Hint:
Consider the function $g(x)=f(x)−x$. Think about the values of $g(x)$ at the endpoints $x=0$ and $x=1$, and use the Intermediate Value Theorem. What can you say about $g(x)$ on the interval $[0,1]$?

item.title: Nilpotent matrix and trace
item.description:
Let $A,B\in \mathcal{M}_n(\mathbb{C})$. Suppose that the matrix $A$ is nilpotent and that the matrix $B$ commutes with $A$. What can be said about $\operatorname{Tr}(AB)$?

Show Hint:
The matrix $AB$ is also nilpotent. Why? And remember (or prove) that $0$ is the only eigenvalue for a nilpotent matrix.

item.title: Computing $\lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn} \frac1 p$ for $k > 1$
item.description:
Prove that

$$ \forall x>0,\quad \frac{1}{1+x}< \ln(1+x)-\ln(x)<\frac1 x.$$

Deduce, for $k\in \mathbb{N}\setminus\{1\}$,

$$\lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn}\frac{1}{p}.$$

Show Answer:
We apply the mean value theorem to the function $t\mapsto \ln t$ on the interval $[x,x+1]$. It exists $c\in (x,x+1)$ such that $$ \ln(1+x)-\ln x= \frac1 c.$$ Since $x < c < x+1$, we have $$\frac1{x+1}<\frac1 c<\frac1 x,$$ and we get the desired result. The bounds $$\lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn} \ln(p+1)-\ln p \le \lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn}\frac1 p\le \lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn} \ln p-\ln(p-1)$$ gives us by telescoping $$\ln \frac{kn+1}{n+1}\le \lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn}\frac1 p\le \ln k.$$ Finally, by the squeeze theorem $$\lim\limits_{n\to+\infty}\sum_{p=n+1}^{kn} \frac1 p=\ln k.$$

item.title: Is the endomorphism $P(X)\mapsto P(X+1)-P(X)$ diagonalizable?
item.description:
Let $n\in \mathbb{N}$, $n\ge 2$. Is the endomorphism $\varphi$ of $\mathbb{C}_n[X]$, which maps the polynomial $P(X)$ to the polynomial $P(X+1)-P(X)$, diagonalizable?

Show Hint:
One may write the matrix of $\varphi $ with respect to a well-chosen basis or reason by contradiction and use the fundemental theorem of algebra.

item.title: Non-Periodicity of a Differentiable Function with a Non-Vanishing Derivative
item.description:
Let $\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}$ be a differentiable function. Assume that $f’$ does not vanish. Show that $f$ cannot be periodic.

Show Answer:
If $f$ is $T$-periodic with $T>0$, then by applying Rolle's Theorem between, for example, 0 and $T$, the derivative of $f$ must vanish.
